Name: COCOA
Institute: University College Cardiff; ATLAS Computer Laboratory

Name: PRORA
Type: text processing; system; concordance; word tagging
Developer: Robert J. Glickman; Gerrit Joseph Staalman
Notes: I. - Card to tape processing; II. - Tape printouts to standard format; III. - Tape printouts to a special format for text processing; IV - Constructing, updating & tagging of master word lists; V. - Use the master word lists to create dictionaries, word indexes and word frequencies; VI. - Partial or complete concordances.  Known via Glickman and Staalman's Manual for the Printing of Literary Texts by Computer (University of Toronto Press, 1966)

Name: PLI
Type: programming language; string processing; list processing
Notes: Described as "a programming language reportedly more suited to humanistic programs than those currently in use. It also seems much easier for humanists to master, with the desirable prospect that they will be able to do their own programming"  (CHum 1.2 p17)
column14: * see Wikipedia for list of mentions and functionality http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PL/I

Name: OPS_3
Developer: Martin Greenberger; Malcolm M. Jones; James H. Morris, Jr.; David N. Ness
Notes: John C. Wells argues that this system, despite its design for numeric data, has a great deal of value for humanities work.

Name: SNOBOL
Notes: Alan Forte wrote a guide called "SNOBOL3 Primer: An Introduction to the Computer Programming Language". Expands to "StriNg Oriented symBOlic Language"

Name: General_Inquirer
Developer: Philip J. Stone; Dexter C. Dunphy; Marshall S. Smith; Daniel G. Ogilvie

Name: FORTRAN
Notes: Programming language commonly mentioned and used in humanistic studies in the 1960s. FORTRAN expands to "FORmula TRANslator"

Name: VIA
Notes: Co-authored the essay "Stylistic Analysis" with Walter Sedelow on indexing and concordance construction, including details of this program.

Name: MAPTEXT
Notes: Co-authored the essay "Stylistic Analysis" with Walter Sedelow on indexing and concordance construction, including details of this program.

Name: STRIP
Notes: A string processing language for linguistics.

Name: STRIL
Developer: G. M. Gillow; K. Heggstad; K. Heggstad
Notes: A conversational programming system developed for linguists for application to Norwegian.

Name: BIBCON
Notes: This program was written in FORTRAN and based on KWIC. A concordance program in reverse (words out of context).

Name: KWIC
Notes: NOTE: KWIC may refer to a tool OR producing a 'key words in context' report. These will have to be disambiguated manually. KWIC is most commonly discussed as a report generated by another program rather than a stand-alone tool.

Name: COMIT
Notes: Programming language taught to humanists specifically to assist humanistic research

Name: COBOL
Notes: Programming language.

Name: ALGOL
Notes: Programming language.

Name: CETA
Institute: Centre pour l'Etude de la Traduction Automatique
Notes: The CETA program is named for its origin, with the Centre pour l'Etude de la Traduction Automatique.

Name: SNAP
Notes: Text processing language developed specifically for humanities research

Name: CLAS
Type: natural language processing; concordance; word count
Developer: George A. Borden; James J. Watts
Notes: Computerized Language Analysis System

Name: EYEBALL
Type: natural language processing; word count; text analysis
Developer: Donald Ross Jr.; Robert H. Rasche
Notes: First developed in PL/I and then converted to FORTRAN

Name: SCAN
Notes: Brown states that he made SCAN's statements similar to BASIC

Name: RATS
Notes: An 'intermediate-level utility written in PL/I'

Name: TEXTAN
Notes: Written in ALGOL 4 to identify Anglicisms in French-language texts

Name: OPCOL
Notes: An algorithm for collating texts and comparing words within them.

Name: EULER
Notes: Programming language proposed as a successor to ALGOL

Tool: SATO; SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur)
Name: SATO
Full: Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur
Developer: Jean-Guy Meunier; Stanislas Rolland; Francois Daoust
Notes: "A textual data processing system for literary and social sciences"

Name: FISHER
Notes: A string-handling package for FORTRAN

Name: INQUIRER
Developer: A. P. M. Coxon; H. R. N. Trappes-Lomas
Notes: A variant on the General Inquirer written in PL/I

Name: LEXICO
Developer: Richard L. Venezky; Nathan Relles; Lynne Price
Institute: University of Delaware; University of Wisconsin-Madison
Notes: System for lexicographic analysis, including functions missing from programs like EYEBALL, SCAN and RATS.

Name: TAP
Type: content analysis; text analysis; concordance; word count
Notes: Written in Assembly Language for the UNIVAC Spectra 70/17

Name: UNICORN
Developer: Michael J. Preston; Samuel S. Coleman
Institute: University of Colorado at Boulder; Lawrence Livermore Laboratory (California)
Notes: An "operational concording system" written in CDC FORTRAN IV

Name: KLIC
Institute: Waterloo Arts Computing Office, University of Waterloo
Notes: Part of an unnamed "concordance package designed by Philip H. Smith of Waterloo"

Name: AUTHOR
Notes: Functions as an interface between RATS and statistical program MINITAB II; assumes knowledge of FORTRAN

Name: HAWKEYE
Notes: Written for an IBM 370 in PL/I. "HAWKEYE is an updated and improved version of the computer program EYEBALL"

Name: CLOC
Notes: "a general purpose text analysis package in the tradition of COCOA, JEUDEMO or OCP" written in ALGOL 68-R

Name: LEMMA
Institute: Institut fur deutsche Sprache, Forschungsstelle Bonn; G. Willfieat tile Institut fur Kommunikationsforschung und Phonetik der Universitat Bonn
Notes: An algorithm/package for lemmatization and morphological analysis of German text

Name: UNICON
Notes: An early concordance generator with a counterpart, UNICOUNT, for word lists and word counts. Written in FORTRAN IV; original developer not clear from the Burton article, but may be Sydney Lamb and Laura Gould, the original describers.

Name: DISCON
Notes: An early concordance program "created to handle bilingual texts"; original developer not clear from the Burton article, but may be Sydney Lamb and Laura Gould, the original describers.

Name: TRICON
Notes: An early concordance program for Russian and other non-Roman alphabet texts, and adapted for Judeo-Arabic texts. Rewritten in FORTRAN G for the IBM 360/370 by Sydney Lamb in 1968; original developer not clear from the Burton article, though created for the Berkeley Machine Translation Project. Developers may be Sydney Lamb and Laura Gould, the original describers.

Tool: Scharfenberg-Smith concordance program; ICRH concordance generator; ICRH (Institute for Computer Research in the Humanities) concordance generator
Name: ICRH
Developer: Kenneth F. Scharfenberg; Philip H. Smith, Jr.
Institute: Thomas J. Watson Research Center; Institute for Computer Research in the Humanities; New York University
Notes: Dolores M. Burton describes this program as "famous".

Name: WATCON
Notes: "given Smith's involvement in its creation, can be regarded as a direct descendant of the Scharfenberg-Smith and ICRH concordance generator"

Name: CONCORD
Notes: An early collocation program that directly influenced COCOA (its features were integrated into later versions of COCOA)

Name: FANGORN
Notes: A programming language for linguistic and literary analysis.

Name: AUTOSTYL
Notes: A package of linked programs for stylistic analysis.

Name: SALEM
Notes: A natural language processing system for German text, written in FORTRAN.

Name: BALCON
Notes: A tool for creating bilingual concordances. Acronym expands to Bilingual Analytical Literary and Linguistic Concordance. Known from an article by Susan (S.M.) Hockey and V. Shibayev referenced in Dolores Burton's article; authorship unclear.

Name: CRIC_8
Notes: CRIC expands to 'cross-reference-in-context'. Authorship unclear from the Dolores Burton article where its is mentioned.

Name: TEXTCORD
Notes: A concordance program developed in SPITBOL for working with texts in scripts other than the Latin alphabet.

Name: COGS
Notes: A general-purpose concordance program.

Name: OCP
Notes: A well-respected concordance program with functions in common with CLOC and COCOA.

Name: DEREDEC
Notes: A French text analysis program.

Name: Icon
Type: programming language; string processing; pattern matching
Notes: A programming language suited to humanistic and linguistic activities developed by a member of the SNOBOL development team.

Name: Donne_Variorum
Developer: Gary A. Stringer; William R. Vilberg
Notes: A collation program developed to assist developing a revised Variorum Edition of the Poetry of John Donne, then released for wider use.

Tool: WordCruncher; Brigham Young University Concordance Program; BYU Concordance
Name: WordCruncher
Notes: Concordance tool first developed as the Brigham Young University Concordance Program, then renamed and slightly revised by the Electronic Text Corporation as WordCruncher.

Name: ARRAS
Notes: Mentioned in brief without further supporting information.

Name: PLC
Notes: A programming language suitable for text analysis and subject of an instructional book, "Programming for the Liberal Arts: An Introduction to PL/C"

Name: FINNMORF
Notes: A lexicography tool for Finnish.

Name: Micro_OCP
Notes: A microcomputer implementation of and expansion on the Oxford Concordance Program.

Name: TEXTPACK
Developer: Peter Mohler; Cornelia Zuell; Juergen Hoehe; Hans-Dieter Klingemann; Klaus Radermacher
Institute: Zentrum fuer Umfragen, Methoden und Analysen (ZUMA)
Notes: A longstanding system of interdependent text analysis utilities. Adapted for microcomputers in the late 1980s.

Name: URICA
Developer: Robert L. Cannon; Robert L. Oakman
Notes: Developed in Turbo Pascal for PCs and compatibles.

Name: SPITBOL
Notes: A programming language used in the humanities and compared favourably to SNOBOL

Name: TACT
Notes: Text analysis tool.

Name: ProIcon
Notes: A programming language for Macintosh with inbuilt text analysis functions. An implementation and update to Icon.

Name: Prolog
Notes: Subject of a manual on using Prolog for computational linguistics

Name: LISP
Notes: Subject of a manual on using LISP for computational linguistics

Name: CLAWS
Notes: Part of Speech tagging tool developed by UCREL at Lancashire Univeristy.

Name: DISCAN
Notes: A content analysis program originally developed for mainframe computers from the Department of Anthropology at Universite Laval in Quebec.

Name: STRAP
Institute: Centre for Computing in the Humanities, University of Toronto
Notes: A suite for structural analysis developed to work with humanities texts. STRAP stands for "structural analysis programs."

Name: VINCI
Notes: Describes a tool developed to take a description of a language and generate sentences from that description.

Name: DYNAKWIC
Notes: Mentioned in brief without further supporting information.

Name: KIMMO
Institute: Summer Institute for Linguistics, Dallas, Texas
Notes: A tool for naturual language processing developed in C and with support for numerous languages such as English, Finnish and Japanese.

Name: Awk
Developer: Alfred V. Aho; Brian W. Kernighan; Peter J. Weinberger
Notes: A programming language that, by the 1988 version, included a variety of functions of specific use to humanities scholars.

Name: Xtract
Notes: A tool developed for lexical collocations and text analysis.

Name: FUNES
Type: natural language processing; tokenization; text analysis
Notes: An NLP system for analyzing short newspaper stories developed in Prolog.

Name: Concorder
Institute: Les Publications CRM, Centre de Recherches Mathematiques, Montreal, Quebec
Notes: A concordance tool with support for multiple languages and versions in French and English.

Name: VOCAB_U_LISTER
Notes: A tool for lemmatizing texts, capable of processing texts in 2000 word segments.

Tool: Morfogen; Morffile/Morfword; Inflword; Version 2.0; Morfogen; Morffile/Morfword; Morffile; Morfword; Inflword
Name: Morfogen
Notes: A suite of tools for morphological analysis.

Name: SimCA
Notes: A program for correspondance analysis developed within the University of South Africa's Department of Statistics

Name: ABFREQ
Notes: A program for identifying key words in a text via frequency analysis.

Tool: Collate; Collate: Interactive Collation of Large Textual Traditions; Collate 2
Name: Collate
Full: Interactive Collation of Large Textual Traditions
Notes: "Collate was designed to process medieval texts that present a wide range of problems not encountered in modern texts" (Johnson review).

Name: Parser_1_0
Notes: A parsing program aimed at academics and running in DOS on PCs and compatibles.

Name: m_EYEBALL
Institute: University of Minnesota; Mary Washington College
Notes: A revision of the original EYEBALL mainframe system for microcomputers.

Name: PANVS
Developer: Khalid J. Al Daimi; Maha A. Abdel-Amir
Notes: A syntactic parser for Arabic text written in PROLOG.

Name: E_Parser
Notes: A syntactic parser implementing a deterministic system.

Name: NETMET
Notes: A program for interpreting and generating metaphors.

Name: REDUX
Notes: A natural language processing system for case reduction (generalization).

Name: ESTMORF
Notes: A tool for morphological analysis of Estonian texts.

Name: TYPICAL
Developer: John Sinclair; Oliver Mason; Jackie Ball; Geoff Barnbrook
Notes: A tool for identifying and assessing the significance of co-occurrances.

Name: COLLOCATE
Developer: John Sinclair; Oliver Mason; Jackie Ball; Geoff Barnbrook
Notes: A tool for "assessing the significance of co-occurring words" in a concordance file.

Name: TATOE
Institute: GMD - Integrated Publication and Information Systems Institute; Center for Survey Research and Methodology (ZUMA)
Notes: A tool useful for concordance and text markup, including export to SGML.

Name: GERTWOL
Notes: A morphological analysis tool for German.

Name: TOSCA
Notes: An analysis system mentioned in brief.

Name: INTEX
Type: text analysis; parsing; natural language processing; concordance
Notes: A tool for concordances and text parsing.

Name: TLC
Developer: Martin Chodorow; Claudia Leacock; George A. Miller
Notes: A trainable system for word sense disambiguation using a Bayesian statistical model.

Name: GINGER
Developer: Luca Dini; Vittorio di Tomaso; Frederique Segond
Institute: Centro per l'Elaborazione del Linguaggio e dell' Informazione; Xerox Research Centre Europe
Notes: A word sense disambiguation system for English.

Name: SUSS
Developer: Jeremy Ellman; Ian Klincke; John Tait
Notes: A word sense disambiguation that competed in SENSEVAL

Name: Grling
Developer: Tom O'Hara; Janyce Wieve; Rebecca Bruce
Institute: New Mexico State University University of North Carolina at Asheville
Notes: A word sense disambiguation that competed in SENSEVAL

Name: Wisdom
Notes: A word sense disambiguation that competed in SENSEVAL

Tool: SENSE (Self-Expanding linguistic knowledge-base for Sense Elicitation); SENSE
Name: SENSE
Full: Self-Expanding linguistic knowledge-base for Sense Elicitation
Developer: Stefano Federici; Simonetta Montemagni; Vito Pirrelli
Notes: A natural language processing system with word sense disambiguation functions that competed in SENSEVAL/ROMANSEVAL

Tool: SCBD (Sentence and Chunk Boundaries Detector); SCBD
Name: SCBD
Developer: E. Stamatatos; N. Fakotakis; G. Kokkinakis
Notes: A natural language processing system with applications for Modern Greek text.

Tool: EXPLEX; EXPLEX (EXtracting information about Proper nouns to provide LEXical inforamtion)
Name: EXPLEX
Full: EXtracting information about Proper nouns to provide LEXical inforamtion
Notes: Developed to process the Wall Street Journal for lexical information.

Name: IITagger
Notes: Developed to apply part of speech tagging to text from the Wall Street Journal.

Tool: GATE; General Architecture for Text Engineering
Name: GATE
Notes: A software architecture for natural language processing.

Name: WinBrill
Institute: Institut National de la Langue Francaise
Notes: A part of speech tagger for Windows distribured by INaLF

Name: Linear_Modelling_Kit
Notes: From the van Pelt article: "Larry Stewart’s Linear Modeling Kit uses computer programming to test the assumptions of structuralist narratology, making their project a robust example of electric theory" (310)

Name: SRILM
Notes: A language modelling toolkit mentioned in an article.

Tool: TUSTEP; TUSTEP (Tübingen System of Text Processing Programs)
Name: TUSTEP
Full: Tübingen System of Text Processing Programs
Notes: A longstanding system of tools for text processing. Now maintained in web form.
